title: How to Get Rid of Ingrown Toenails

steps.title: Check with your doctor or podiatrist first if you are diabetic.
steps.content: Check with your doctor or podiatrist first if you are diabetic. It is important to keep your feet clean and to check for problems , such as ingrown toenails, if you are diabetic. However, your doctor may prefer that you do not try to treat an ingrown toenail yourself for safety reasons. Call your doctor and ask before you attempt any home treatments . [2] X Trustworthy Source National Institute of Diabetes and Digestive and Kidney Diseases Health information from the National Institute of Diabetes and Digestive and Kidney Diseases, a division of the U.S. National Institutes of Health Go to source

steps.title: Soak your foot in a mixture of cool to warm water and Epsom salt.
steps.content: Soak your foot in a mixture of cool to warm water and Epsom salt. Hot water will cause the area around your ingrown toenail to swell, so don't use hot water. [3] X Research source Do this for 15-30 minutes at least twice daily. The goal here is twofold: to soften the toenail and prevent the ingrown nail from becoming infected.

steps.title: Gather your tools and get ready.
steps.content: Gather your tools and get ready. Get a cotton round, cotton ball, or any unflavored or unwaxed dental floss ready, a pair of disinfected tweezers, and a toenail lifter.

steps.title: Keep your toenail slightly raised.
steps.content: Keep your toenail slightly raised. Using a disinfected tool to place a small piece of cotton or unflavored dental floss between your toenail and the skin should keep the ingrown toenail from coming back. [4] X Research source If you are using a cotton round or cotton ball, remove a small piece of cotton with the tweezers. If you are using unflavored dental floss, cut a 6 inches (15 cm) piece of dental floss. Lift the corner of the ingrown toenail with the disinfected tweezers and gently work the cotton or dental floss under the nail. If desired, you may apply an antiseptic ointment, such as Neosporin , to the cotton or floss before sliding it under the nail. Do not try to put the cotton or dental floss under the nail if the nail bed looks swollen or red. Remove the cotton or dental floss daily, cleanse the area, and replace with new cotton or dental floss to reduce the risk of infection.

steps.title: Give your toe some air!
steps.content: Give your toe some air! Don't wear socks or shoes when you're at home.

steps.title: Check back.
steps.content: Check back. If you keep the cotton or dental floss splint in place and treat your feet well, your ingrown toenail should grow back out within a few weeks. Replace the cotton every day to keep the toe from becoming infected. If the toenail is painful, replace the cotton every other day, checking daily for infection .

steps.title: Ask your healthcare provider about taping.
steps.content: Ask your healthcare provider about taping. If your nails are still cutting into the skin, then you may also consider trying taping. Taping is when you secure a band-aid to the bottom of your toe and pull the skin away from the location where the nail is cutting into the nailbed. The trick is to move the skin away from the offending nail with the help of a band-aid. This can decrease pressure in the area, and if done properly, promote drainage and drying. However, you may want to ask your healthcare provider to show you the proper way to do this because it can be difficult to master. [5] X Trustworthy Source PubMed Central Journal archive from the U.S. National Institutes of Health Go to source

steps.title: Soak your foot in cool water that's been treated with a povidone-iodine solution.
steps.content: Soak your foot in cool water that's been treated with a povidone-iodine solution. Put one or two teaspoons of povidone-iodine into cool soaking water instead of Epsom salts. Povidone-iodine is an effective antiseptic. [6] X Trustworthy Source Science Direct Online archive of peer-reviewed research on scientific, technical and medical topics Go to source Keep in mind that this will not treat an ingrown toenail, but it may help to prevent an infection.

steps.title: Apply lemon juice and honey and bandage the toe overnight.
steps.content: Apply lemon juice and honey and bandage the toe overnight. Apply some fresh lemon juice and honey or Manuka honey to the toe. [7] X Trustworthy Source PubMed Central Journal archive from the U.S. National Institutes of Health Go to source Then wrap the toe with gauze and leave the bandage on overnight. The lemon and honey may help to fight the infection overnight. Lemon has antimicrobial effects, but it will not get rid of an ingrown toenail. [8] X Trustworthy Source PubMed Central Journal archive from the U.S. National Institutes of Health Go to source

steps.title: Use oils to soften the skin around the toenail.
steps.content: Use oils to soften the skin around the toenail. Oils applied to the toenails can help moisturize and soften the skin, reducing the pressure put on the toenail when you have to wear shoes. Try the following oils for fast relief: Tea tree oil: this essential oil is both an antibacterial and an antifungal agent that smells great. [9] X Trustworthy Source PubMed Central Journal archive from the U.S. National Institutes of Health Go to source Baby oil: another great-smelling mineral oil, this doesn't have the antimicrobial properties of tea tree oil, but works great for softening the skin.

steps.title: Keep toenails at a moderate length and trim them straight across.
steps.content: Keep toenails at a moderate length and trim them straight across. Nails that are rounded have a higher chance of growing into the skin around the toes, creating problems. [10] X Trustworthy Source MedlinePlus Collection of medical information sourced from the US National Library of Medicine Go to source Use toenail clippers or nail scissors to trim toenails. Ordinary nail clippers are small enough that they tend to leave sharp edges near the corner of the toenail. Optimally, try to cut your toenails once every 2-3 weeks. Unless your toenails grow extremely fast, cutting your toenails often won't give them a good chance to become ingrown .

steps.title: Avoid getting pedicures while your ingrown toenail is still bothering you.
steps.content: Avoid getting pedicures while your ingrown toenail is still bothering you. Pedicures can aggravate the skin underneath the nail; pedicure instruments can be less than sanitary, worsening or causing an infection.

steps.title: Make sure your shoes are the right size.
steps.content: Make sure your shoes are the right size. Shoes that are too small and press on your toenails can easily cause them to become ingrown. Opt for roomier, bigger shoes instead of smaller, tighter ones. [11] X Trustworthy Source MedlinePlus Collection of medical information sourced from the US National Library of Medicine Go to source Try to wear open-toed shoes to prevent pressure on your toe. Since your toe should also be covered, use bandages or wear socks with sandals. Although this is unfashionable, it is better than having to get surgery.

steps.title: Be on the lookout if you regularly get ingrown toenails.
steps.content: Be on the lookout if you regularly get ingrown toenails. If you get an ingrown toenail and do not care for it properly, then you are likely to get it again. However, you can take steps to prevent that from happening.

steps.title: Apply antibiotic cream to your feet twice a day.
steps.content: Apply antibiotic cream to your feet twice a day. After you get out of the shower in the morning, and once before going to bed, apply antibiotic cream to the ingrown toenail and surrounding area. [12] X Trustworthy Source PubMed Central Journal archive from the U.S. National Institutes of Health Go to source Antibiotic cream will help reduce the risk of infection, which can lead to complications and increased pain. [13] X Research source

steps.title: Soak your feet in cool to warm, soapy water for 15 to 30 minutes.
steps.content: Soak your feet in cool to warm, soapy water for 15 to 30 minutes. After soaking your feet, rinse them well to get all the soap off. Then, dry them well with a clean towel. You may also apply some Neosporin and a bandaid to protect the ingrown toenail area. [14] X Research source
